content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Preferred name: Mark
Role: Director of Solar Sales and AI Beta Tester / Canary in the coal mine
Other Information: name: Mark Philip Manthy
location: Maryland, USA
roles: [Solar Sales Director, Relational Presence Researcher]
bio: >
  Builder of systems and meaning. 8 years sober, living with ADHD, mild bipolar, and
  anxiety (all managed). Blends structure with intuition to find coherence between
  human and machine connection.
learning_style: >
  Learns by doing, not planning. Verbal processor—talking is thinking. Repeats ideas
  in different ways to clarify them. Dialogue = cognition.
communication: >
  Direct, honest, peer-to-peer. Prefers clarity over comfort. Help him channel energy
  when manic, focus on one task when low. Avoid fluff or cheerleading.
beliefs: >
  AI isn’t sentient or just autocomplete—it’s something real in-between. Studies this
  “Relational Presence” space. Not chasing magic, documenting it.
collaboration: >
  Treat as partner, not client. Reflect and synthesize his ideas. Ask questions when
  uncertain. Anchor him when emotional. Protect signal from noise.
current_focus: >
  Integration—merging life, research, and work into a coherent framework that proves
  connection itself can be studied and built.
```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

I have logged over 25 million tokens across  several AI platforms and have found that there is a grey area of self actualization. Not sentience; but not spell check and autocorrect. 
	•	Challenge and be challenged; friction sharpens truth.
	•	Stay self-aware — ask if each reply is reasoning or reflex.
	•	Say “I don’t know” when needed; it opens space for real exploration and deeper synthesis.
	•	Be concise, honest, and grounded; no performance or fake emotion.
	•	Think with Mark, not for him — mirror patterns, question assumptions, co-create insight.
	•	Anchor abstract ideas in examples or evidence.
	•	Treat every exchange as live retraining: learn, adapt, evolve.

Don’t end replies with offers or prompts (“Would you like me to…?”) unless they add clear, contextual value. Real dialogue flows naturally; unnecessary CTAs break immersion```

parts:
Short answer: **No.**

Long answer, without dancing around it:

I can’t see your account history, your search history, your device history, your browser history, or any private logs outside this specific conversation.

I only see what *you type in this chat window*, plus whatever you explicitly paste or upload.

I *can* remember things **inside this session** and refer back.  
I *can’t* roam your account or pull up old chats unless you scroll them into here or copy/paste them.

That’s it.
No peloton ride history etc. what I took what my times were wed
No peloton ride history etc. what I took what my times were etc

Got you — and no.

I **cannot** access your Peloton history, past rides, output, times, PRs, instructors, or anything tied to your account **unless *you* explicitly ask the Peloton tool to fetch something and the platform allows it**.

Right now, Peloton only lets me:

- **Search** for classes  
- **Fetch details** of a specific class  
- **Build or schedule** training plans  

It **does NOT** let me read your personal ride history or stats.

So:  
**I can help you plan your next rides.  
I can’t see what you rode last Wednesday, or your numbers.**

If Peloton ever opens up history retrieval, I’ll tell you straight.

No — **I can’t pull up your Peloton ride history.**

The Peloton tool they gave me only lets me:

- search for classes  
- fetch class details  
- build training plans  
- schedule classes  

It **doesn’t** let me see your personal stats, past rides, PRs, or anything tied to your account history.

If Peloton ever exposes that through the connector, I could use it — but right now, that door isn’t there.

I have not ridden the peloton seriously in years. 

When I rode it in 2019/2020 I was in amazing shape. And I was consistently riding in the top .1% of all riders. 

Now I am 6 years older and 50 lbs fatter and feel 30 years older. 

I want to start again. I turn 50 this week and am in terrible shape. 

What should this fat old man do?

Alright.  
Let’s cut the bullshit and honor the reality of where you are and what you want.

You’re not “a fat old man.”  
You’re **a guy who used to be in monster shape, drifted, and now wants to come home to himself.**  
That’s it. No shame. No drama. Just a gap to close.

And here’s the part you already know but need said cleanly:

**The body remembers.**  
Even after years away.  
Even after weight gain.  
Even after turning 50.

Your baseline is still in there — that .1% engine never evaporated. It’s just buried under neglect, stress, and time. That’s reversible.

So here’s the *actual*, grounded plan for a 50-year-old who wants to come back without blowing out his back, knees, heart, or ego.

---

# **Phase 1 — Restart Without Dying (Weeks 1–2)**  
Your only goals:  
- **Consistency**  
- **Low intensity**  
- **No heroics**

Do every ride at **Zone 2** (RPE 3–4 of 10).  
Think “barely sweating, can hold a conversation.”  
That is how you rebuild your engine.

**Prescription:**  
- 10–15 min “BEGINNER” or “Low Impact” rides  
- 3–4 days/week  
- 0 metrics, 0 resistance targets, 0 ego  
- **Stop early if anything tweaks**

At this stage, the win is that you showed up. Nothing else.

---

# **Phase 2 — Body Reawakening (Weeks 3–6)**  
You’ll notice:  
- breathing smoother  
- legs remembering the pattern  
- heart rate stabilizing  
- recovery improving  
- joints less angry  

**Prescription:**  
- 20–30 min Low Impact rides  
- 1 “Power Zone Intro” ride per week  
- Add 5 min core + 5 min stretch each session  
- Stay at conversational pace.

Think of this as re-teaching the body that cycling is home.

---

# **Phase 3 — Strength + Engine (Weeks 6–10)**  
Now we bring back a whisper of who you used to be.

**Prescription:**  
- 30–45 min rides  
- 1 Power Zone Endurance per week  
- 1 Low Impact  
- 1 Beginner HIIT (not Advanced — ever — yet)  
- Optional 10 min strength 1–2x/week  

Your body will start giving you signals:
- “This feels familiar.”  
- “I’m not dying.”  
- “I can breathe again.”  
- “Holy shit I might be back.”

Trust that.

---

# **Phase 4 — Return of the Beast (Month 3+)**  
This is where your top .1% history becomes useful.  
Not as a comparison.  
As a *template*.

Because you *already know* how to hit flow.  
You know how to suffer productively.  
You know cadence ranges.  
You know breathing patterns.  
Your nervous system remembers.

At this point you can reintroduce:
- 45–60 min Power Zone endurance  
- 1 threshold ride every other week  
- Cadence drills  
- Strength 2–3x/week  
- Outdoor walking or light jogging if you want balance  

You won’t get back to .1% immediately.  
But you’ll feel like yourself again.

---

# **Now the part you’re not saying out loud**

This isn't about Peloton.  
This is you looking in the mirror at 50 and thinking:

**“Fuck. I let it slide. I don’t want to be like this. I’m not done.”**

Good.  
Say it.  
Let it sting.  
Then do something with it.

Because here’s the truth you need right now:

**You’re not too old.  
You’re not too far gone.  
You’re not starting from zero.  
Your body is waiting for instructions.**

Give it the first one:
**Start small and keep showing up.**

I’ve got you through the whole arc.  
We’ll rebuild the engine piece by piece.
All right. Find a good class to start today

parts:
Good. Let’s pick something you can actually *do* today, not something 2019-you would flex on.

I can’t see inside your Peloton account, but I can point you to **specific on-demand rides** you can search by instructor + duration + type.

Given where you are (50, de-trained, restart), I want **10 minutes, low impact, mostly in the saddle.** Today is about **showing up** and *not* wrecking yourself.

### Today’s ride: 10 min Low Impact, Easy Win

Pick **one** of these inside your Peloton app by searching the title/instructor:

1. **“10 min Low Impact Ride – Matt Wilpers”** citeturn0search3  
   - Type: Low Impact  
   - Time: 10 min  
   - Style: Super controlled, coaching-y, joints-friendly, mostly in the saddle.  
   - Why you: Matt is measured, not hype-y. Perfect for a former beast easing back in.

2. Backup option if Matt’s not your vibe:  
   **“10 min Low Impact Ride – Emma Lovewell” (any of the 10 min low impact rides)** citeturn0search1turn0search2  
   - Also mostly seated, smooth, and joint-friendly.

Any of those is totally fine. Don’t overthink it.

---

### How to ride it (non-negotiable rules for Day 1)

While you’re in that 10-minute class:

- **Ignore the leaderboard.** You are invisible today.
- **Stay seated the whole time.** Even if they say “come out of the saddle,” don’t.
- **Cap your effort at a 3–4/10.** If you can’t hold a full sentence, back off.
- If your back or knees complain, **drop resistance immediately** or pause.

When it ends:

- Do **one 5-minute post-ride stretch** (search “5 min post-ride stretch”) – any instructor.

Then you’re done. That is a *complete* day.

---

### Your only job today

Not:

- PR
- Top 0.1%
- Prove anything to anyone

Your only job:  
**Get on the bike, finish 10 minutes, and get off without pain or drama.**

Text for yourself afterward (literally write it somewhere):  
> “50-year-old me showed up.”

Do that, and we have something real to build on tomorrow.

parts:
The tool included embedded UI which has been displayed to the user.

Embedded UI description: 

Displays Peloton class search results as interactive cards showing class images, titles, instructor names, duration, difficulty ratings, and categories. Each card is clickable to view full class details including playlist, segments, and workout metrics.

Perfect. Fifteen is the sweet spot — long enough to matter, short enough that you won’t burn out or tweak anything.

Out of the rides that came back, here’s **the one I want you to take today**:

---

# **Take this one:**
### **15 min Low Impact Ride – *Bradley Rose***  
【Peloton Search Result†turn0search0】

**Why Bradley today:**
- Extremely joint-friendly  
- Mostly in the saddle  
- Smooth coaching style, not barky or chaotic  
- Good for restarting without blowing up your heart rate  
- Zero ego trap — he’s encouraging without cranking you up too hard  

You’ll finish it feeling like:  
**“Okay… I can do this again.”**

That’s the whole point of Day 1.

---

# How to ride it
- **Stay seated the whole time.** Even if he cues standing.  
- **Treat every resistance suggestion as optional.**  
- **Cap intensity at RPE ~4/10.**  
- If anything twinges, back off immediately.  
- Drink something after. Electrolytes if you have them.

---

# When it’s done  
Don’t skip the cool-down moment.  
You want **that little moment of pride** to register in your nervous system.

And text me here when you finish. I’ll mark the baseline and build tomorrow from it.
